title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Colombian flag




Colombia, situated at the northern tip of South America, is a country of remarkable diversity and charm. Boasting a population of over 50 million, it’s a melting pot of cultures, from indigenous communities to descendants of Spanish colonizers and African slaves. The country spans a variety of landscapes, from the Andes Mountains to the Amazon rainforest, Caribbean and Pacific coastlines.



Colombia map

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Days 1-4: Medellín
Medellín has transformed into a city of innovation and culture.

Day 1 (Sun March 2)

Morning:Flight to Medellín (DCA to MIA, MIA to MDE)
Afternoon: Arrival and hotel check-in
Evening: Dinner and cultural exchange



Day 2 (Mon March 3)

Morning: Class time
Afternoon: Visit to Comuna 13



Day 3 (Tue March 4)

Morning: Class time
Afternoon: Medellin Afro City Tour



Day 4 (Wed March 5)

Morning: Checkout of hotel; transfer to Cartegena
Afternoon: School/excursion and hotel check-in

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Days 5-8: Cartagena and Palenque
Cartagena, a UNESCO World Heritage site, offers a perfect blend of Caribbean atmosphere and colonial charm. Palenque is an historic African village in Colombia.

Day 5 (Thu March 6)

Morning: Day trip to San Basilio de Palenque
Afternoon: Return to Cartagena



Day 6 (Fri March 7)

Morning: Travel to Rosario Island Beach
Afternoon: Beach Day



Day 7 (Sat March 8)

Morning: Checkout and departure (CTG to MIA, MIA to DCA)
Afternoon: Return to DCA

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Clothing

Lightweight, breathable clothing for hot weather
Long-sleeved shirts and pants for mosquito protection
Rain jacket or poncho
Swimwear for beach day
Light sweater or jacket for cooler evenings
Comfortable walking shoes
Sandals or flip-flops

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Accessories

Sun hat
Sunglasses
Daybag for excursions
Reusable water bottle
Travel locks

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Electronics

Smartphone and charger
Camera
Universal travel adapter

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Toiletries

Sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher)
Insect repellent
Hand sanitizer
Personal medications

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Documents

Passport (valid for at least 6 months beyond March 1, 2025)
Credit cards and some cash
Copies of important documents

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Visa and Entry Requirements

Currently, U.S. visitors can enter Colombia without a visa for stays up to 90 days.
You’ll need a passport valid for at least 6 months beyond your planned return date.
Check the Colombian Ministry of Foreign Affairs website for the most up-to-date information.

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Language
Spanish is the official language. While English is spoken in some tourist areas, learning basic Spanish phrases will greatly enhance your experience and interactions with locals. We will practice some of these typical phrases in class.

title: Colombia Pre-Departure Packet
text:
Money

The currency is the Colombian Peso (COP).
Credit cards are widely accepted in cities and tourist areas.
ATMs are readily available in urban areas.
Inform your bank of your travel plans to avoid card blocks.

We will be checking the latest travel advisories and health requirements before our trip. ¡Buen viaje!

title: Historical Figures
text:
Ralph Bunche


Ralph Johnson Bunche was born on August 7, 1904 in Detroit, Michigan. He became a pioneering diplomat, academic, and civil rights activist. In 1928, Bunche joined the faculty of Howard University, where he founded the Political Science Department. He was the first African American to earn a Ph.D. in political science from Harvard University in 1934.
The Ralph J. Bunch International Affairs Center, Directed by Dr. Tonija Hope, is located here at Howard!
His groundbreaking diplomatic work transformed international relations. In 1946, he joined the United Nations as director of the Trusteeship Division and in 1949 successfully negotiated armistice agreements between Israel and four Arab states, for which he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1950, becoming the first African American and person of color to receive this honor. Bunche’s influence extended to the civil rights movement, participating in key events like the 1963 March on Washington and the 1965 Selma to Montgomery Voting Rights March alongside Martin Luther King Jr.









Mary McCleod Bethune


Mary McLeod Bethune was born on July 10, 1875 in Mayesville, South Carolina. She was the first of her 17 siblings to be born free from slavery. She became a pioneering educator, civil rights activist, and a women’s rights advocate. In 1904, Bethune founded the Daytona Normal and Industrial Training Institute for Negro Girls with just $1.50, which later merged with Cookman Institute to become Bethune-Cookman College, now a university. She also established the first hospital for Black people in Daytona Beach, Florida, in 1911.
Bethune’s work had a significant impact on international affairs and education.
She was the only woman of color at the founding conference of the United Nations in 1945, where she served as an associate consultant to the US delegation in drafting the UN charter. Her focus during these negotiations was on the rights of people living in colonized countries worldwide. Bethune’s Pan-African activism extended her influence throughout the African diaspora, as she worked to create solidarity among Africans globally through her writings and travels.
